text:
28/VI/16 - 12Fl. Oz. bottle @ the pre-AdamChandler-tasting, Erwins ponton - BB: n/a, bottled: 18/XI/15 (2016-710) Thanks to ElManana+1 for sharing the bottle!
Clear red brown beer, big creamy beige head, pretty stable, bit adhesive. Aroma: lots and lots of coffee, roasted touch, dried fruits. MF: soft carbon, medium to full body. Taste: bit sourish, fruity, lots of coffee flavour, overripe banana. Aftertaste: bitter touch, sweet malts, some chocolate, vanilla.

UPDATED: AUG 5, 2016 Tap at new bohemia in golden valley. 10oz pour. Black with small off white head. Smells of alcohol and chocolate . Smooth, sweet flavor with some chocolate elements. More flavor development as it warms. Good. Glad the devil made me do it.
Bottle at Erwin's Place. Oatmeal, chocolate, roast, coffee, very nice beer. Love it.

A dark brown stout with a thin dark brown head. In aroma, sweet fruity chocolate malt with light coffee notes, grassy hops, very nice. In mouth, a nice sweet fruity chocolate malt with light coffee notes, light vanilla, alcohol warmth, very nice and smooth. Bottle at Cigar and Stripes BBQ.
On tap @ Radio Maria. Black and viscous with a persistent khaki head. Loads of creamy coffee character, silky mouthfeel, full and richly roasty, moderately bitter finish. Yum.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Pours a nice very dark brown with a medium tan head. Aroma is dark fruit. Taste is sweet roasted malt, dark fruit, chocolate milk and a bit of espresso. Surprisingly smooth and creamy for the style.
Bottle. Pours black with thin tan head. Aroma of coffee, malt and chocolate. Taste is sweet chocolate and coffee with a malty coffee finish. Very good.
Bottle shared with dusty and Brian...nose is all coffee and a dark roast at that....taste mellows out a lot...more oatmeal comes and the coffee doesnt dominate.
tap. kind of average imperial porter. nothing really jumped out - was very robust, but kind of bland
Amazing vanilla wood barrel and bourbon nose. With lots of coffee aroma. Coffee however on tongue is almost to strong. Still a great light sweetness and a great beer.

Bottle. Dark brown pour with not much head. Aroma is rich chocolate and coffee. Flavour is malty chocolate, some coffee - not particularly roasty for a porter, and not as rich as expected for the ABV, but still good.
Bottle via trade. Dark brown pour with almost no head. Aromas of coffee and roast. Silky mouthfeel. I dont know. Its ok.
Bottle at Craigs tastingSlightly fruity tomatoey chilli and coffee on nose. Fruity,Smokey, coffee, a little sharp, cocoa. Light, dry finish.
Bottle. Near black with tan head. Aroma of roasty coffee, slightly fruity licorice. Taste is roasty, burnt, coffee. Slightly sweet.

bottle at home ...steve tasting ... dark brown ... thin tan lacing ... soft coffee chocolate roast ... soft fruit malt nose ... dark sweet roast .. soft malts .. soft sweet chcolate roast .. ligth sweet coffee ... mellow soft coffee roast

Bottle at Craigs. Pours clear dark brown with a thin tan head. Aromas of green vegetables, peppers, coffee. Taste is roasted bitter, coffee on the finish. 

12th July Garvie tasting
Bottle at craigs. Pours black, nose is chocolate, coffee, roasted, taste is similar, quite dry, oatmeal, rich.

Wonderful beer from a brewery I?ve hitherto never heard of. Why doesn?t anyone talk about these guys? Lots of coffee and chocolate. Roast malt. Black pour with great mocha head and lacing. Thick consistency. Bitter finish with hint of caramel sweetness. Bottle.

This is a really great shelf beer for Porter/Stout enthusiasts. Dont know why it doesnt get more love but nice coffee aroma that pours thick and dark. Taste is nice coffee, with chocolate notes. Its only seasonal but worth picking up a few of the 4 packs when you can. Great great great beer to grab when you dont feel like opening a bomber or rare beer.

Pours pitch black with a large tan head. Smells strongly of coffee. Taste is bold coffee with hints of chocolate. Full-bodied with a smooth, silky texture and soft mouth-carbonation, Tyranena The Devil Made Me Do It finishes with a smooth coffee bitterness.

Pours black with very little tan head. Aroma is roast malts. Nice medium body. Fresh coffee and roast malt profile is really good. More bitter than the average coffee stout, some piney hops.Good stuff.
Ooh la la. Great coffee influence on a solid porter, meaning each complements the others role in the taste profile. Part of a dependable line of shouts & porters from this brewer.
Bottle. Pours a very dark brown with small beige head. The aroma is strong coffee roast and chocolate. Medium mouth strong dark chocolate, sweet roasted malt, light dry finish.
Dark pour with a beige head. Aroma is roasted malt and coffee. Taste is YUM! Coffee, roasted malt, oatmeal, creamy. Big, bold, long lasting flavor. OK lacing.
Big coffee aroma. Smells like a starbucks. Taste is sweet mocha. Lots of coffee and chocolate. Very good.

Bottle. Pours opaque black with creamy beige head. Aroma is heavy coffee and chocolate, medium roast, some earthiness, and some barrel character. Flavor echoes the nose and is coffee and chocolate dominant with some booze, vanilla sweetness, and oak. Slightly thinner than I expected with medium body and soft carbonation.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle, nice dark brown color, smooth creamy tan head. Coffee comes thru right away, roasted malt, just a hint of cocoa. Dont let me forget the oatmeal. A very silky smooth beer. I really enjoyed this beer.

As a sidebar, I dont really like a beer after dinner but this one worked. Made a fine dessert. Try it!

Black pour with a one finger, creamy caramel brown head that has excellent retention and leaves some pretty nice lacing. Aroma is roast, sharp medium to dark roast coffee, roasted nuts, toasty granola and light grassy hops. Flavor is sweet chocolate, toffee nuts, medium roast coffee seemingly to the fruitier side of profiles, a little earth, roast, toasted grains and dark caramel. Medium to heavy body, creamy entry, creamy to goopy middle and thinner, still creamy, but drier finish. Light, blanketing and slightly too sharp carbonation, which is a bit to sharp for me. I can taste oatmeal clearly in my burps, but not nearly as well in the beer, that is weird.

Coffee and cocoa aroma. Black in color with light frothy head. Flavor of chocolate and slight coffee taste. I also taste and smell Serrano peppers, though no heat from the peppers. Good balance of malt and hops.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2015 On tap, poured into a snifter. Theres lots of coffee in the aroma along with oats and a touch of caramel late (as it warms). Its a dark, opaque, red-brown beer with a tan foam head which retains a medium ring and a wispy surface. The taste is a medium sweet and medium high bitter. It?s oily and fizzy with a medium full body containing flavors of coffee, oats, chocolate, and caramel. It finishes with roasted bitter coffee and it has a syrupy chocolate and coffee aftertaste.

12fl oz bottle poured into a pint glass. Black or near enough with a small brown cap. Aroma is coffee beans. Flavor is coffee. Thick creamy full body. Decent. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 ounce bottle from Timfoolery, chocolate and coffee, jet black, mildly sweet. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours opaque dark mahogany with a thin khaki head. Aroma is dark chocolate with a bit of sweetness. Taste is coffee, ash, and dark chocolate. Not bad oatmeal porter n

[ Bottle ][ 12oz ][ Discount Liquors Milkwaukee ][ $3 ][ Woodshop Snifter ][ 10.24.14 ]
>> Pours clear deep brown producing an inky pour in the glass with large, brown foam. Okay retention and spotty lacing. Nose is sharper green cheap coffee and jalapeño. Moves to richer creme brulee, spicy pepper, vanilla bean, huge cinnamon graham cracker, dark cherry. Taste up front is bubbly, clean, medium bodied, low lemon acid, dark cherry soda. Super clean finish, coconut, mild to almost no coffee, no harshness. Easy to enjoy, no off flavors. Great stuff.

Bottle thanks to bytemesis. Pours dark brown with reddish highlights. Thin layer of fine bubbles. Aroma: coffee and oatmeal chocolate chip cookie. Taste: coffee dominates here. Still plenty of chocolate, but sweetness is muted. Assertive coffee bitterness in the finish. Palate: medium+ body that doesnt quite hold up to the fullness of the taste. Silky texture, average carbonation. Overall: I repeat: coffee with oatmeal chocolate chip cookie - 2 parts coffee to 1 part cookie.
Hotel Borefts 14. Trade with Hannont. Thanks Todd. Pours black with a creamy head. Mocha, roast and a vinous round creamy and smooth palate. Very slick. Lovely!

Sampled bottle @ Borefts Hotel room. Thank you Dedollewaitor / Mads & Christian! Fell asleep during some part of this tasting as usual. Vintage bottle if I am correct. Black little mocha. Strong soy sauce nose, thick roast, liquorish, syrupy, caramel, brown sugar, chocolate, rich, caramel, sweet coffee,.. Rich body, quite nice.
Black with a small off white head. Aroma of coffee liqueur, caramel and vanilla. Sweetish malty flavour with sweet coffee notes, chocolate and toffee. Like a thin Kalua...

"Opens up so nicely. Roasted coffee, earthy hops, a touch of chocolate on the nose. The flavor is a little more bitter than sweet, more earthy coffee beans and a touch of hops. Nicely balanced and very smooth. High quality across the board. Started out a high 3, but got better every sip. Thanks Heybeerman for the trade."
Rich earthy coffee and dark cocoa bitterness with hints of the fruitiness Ive had from some dark chocolates. Quite tasty, though the coffee isnt my favorite "type" of coffee flavor.

Bottle from my Secret Summer Santa 2014. Pours black as Coke with a small creamy tanned head. Aroma of dark malts, coffee, tar and liquorice. Smooth and oily mouthfeel.Lots of coffee in the taste, oatmeal and dark bitter chocolate, lovely lingering coffee.

The Brewers Gone Wild series is consistently excellent and this super-smooth porter is a terrific example. Lots of coffee and chocolate in the aroma and just a tiny hint of bitterness more out of the chocolate than any stray hops. Well worth tracking down when its in season.

Approx. 2 year cellared 12 oz. bottle, shared and poured to snifters, showing a black/brown hue, with some ruby highlighting, a modest layer of tan head foam, and spots & strands of lacing. The nose started with a bit of salty soy, then roasted notes, cocoa, a little syrupy sweetness, molasses, coffee, and a hint of earthy peat on the back. Medium bodied, the texture was a little watery, with soft carbonation, a conglomeration of the aroma notes with no one standing out, and a slightly tart edge to the finish. Not bad, but didnt hold up to the cellaring as I would have liked, and lost most of the oatmeal influence.

Bottle from Discount Liquors in Milwaukee.

Served alongside the barrel-aged version.

Dark brown body with a small beige head. Lovely aroma, consisting of rich coffee, freshly ground coffee beans, bready malts, roast, chocolate - everything youd expect from reading the label. Nice flavor. Oats and coffee play so well together. Super smooth while maintaining a bold and assertive coffee presence throughout. A fine example of a coffee porter / stout.
Pours a dark black color with tan head. Coffee, roasted malt, and some cocoa on the nose; follows onto the palate. Finishes with more coffee.
Coffee, toast, roast malt, earth. Dark almost black with a thick quickly fading light tan head. Medium bodied. Deep roasted coffee flavor. Smooth with a mildly sharp finish. Dry mouthfeel. Nice.
Pours thick dark rich coffee with a darker beige head. Aroma is amazing, big coffee with some sweet mocha and vanilla. Flavor brings coffee and roasted bitter malts on a smooth creamy body.

12 ounce bottle. Pours almost black with a decent tan head. Aroma of malt, coffee, and chocolate. Taste is roasted malt, coffee, dark chocolate, and some alcohol. Oats give it a somewhat creamy body. Nice.

Via trade with Crajun Beautiful aroma of coffee, bitter chocolate. The appearance is jet black, light tan head. The flavor is coffee, cream, dark chocolate. The finish is roasty, bitter chocolate. Medium to medium/thick in body. Nice.

36cl, as Tyranena Brewers Gone Wild! The Devil Made Me Do It!, exclusive American brew, with coffee, thx alot to Koen for bringing this over!, complex Porter, malty/roasted and slightly sweet/smoked, balanced, cloudy, nearly no head, good brew
Decent coffee beer, but not among the elite class for this category. A bit watery, but still a good beer

Pours inky black out of the bottle with a 1/4" of frothy foam on top. Smells of coffee and roasted malt. tastes primarily of coffee (go figure) with hints of chocolate, with some hop flavor. As flavor fades the mouth is overtaken by coffee bitterness. overall a good beer- a bit thin for my liking but then it probably would have been a stout.

This one poured a black as night color with a beige head. Aroma was of lots and lots of fresh coffee, some grain, roasted malt and dark chocolate. Flavor was again huge coffee, but not coffeee bitterness at all, incredibly smooth and just mouth watering stuff.

Seriously tasty. But not cloying. Good balance of the coffee. Sweetnesst. Alcohol and finish

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pour (Happy Gnome Beer Dinner) black with a tan head, tastes of chocolate, coffee, and malt, very good.

12oz. bottle. Full-on roasty coffee aroma, dark and rich with hints of cocoa, raisin and molasses. Murky dark brown/black in color with a very thin, fading head. Flavor profile is full of dark malt, chocolate and dark, roasty coffee, with a very mild background sweetness to nicely balance out the dry, bitter malts and earthy hop character, some lingering fudgy chocolate, smoke and roast at the finish. Very low in effervescence with a mostly dry yet lightly coating mouthfeel and a full body. Quite flavorful and tasty.

Deep rich black color with short tan head. Nose is a pleasant mix of fresh coffee beans and chocolate malt. The oatmeal gives a nice full body and complements the flavors really well. A nice creamy, silky texture, very closely resembling a milk consistency.

Bottle. Pours a dark black with no head. Aroma is pure fresh roasted espresso coffee, and fresh ground coffee grinds. Taste is pure coffee and espresso, flavorful with subtle sweetness and chocolate. Finishes on the caffeinated notes. Utterly enjoyable, like Chock Full of Nuts......a heavenly cup. Quaff Score 9 / 10

Pours black with a brown head and nice aroma of coffee and chocolate. Taste is delicious, lots of rich coffee espresso notes along with sweet milk chocolate, roasted malt, and oatmeal with a roasty, burnt finish. Lots of flavor, great coffee style porter

Deep black in color... Silky mouthfeel... Aroma of roasted malts, oats, smoke, coffee... Flavor is light roast coffee, dark chocolate, smoke... Smokey finish... Nice beer

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from locals trade with MadBeerBaron. Pours brown/black with minimal tan head. Aroma is light roasted coffee, vanilla, charcoal. Taste is nice coffee kick upfront with a smooth, round nutty sweetness. Coffee is not pervasive here but is a nice player in the overall taste. Oatmeal smooths it out and gives a sweetness. Really nice beer.

Black oily pour with a ruby/brown hue, khaki creamy head, and light sticky lacing .... aroma is of a wonderful fresh roasted coffee, roasted malts, dark chocolate, dark burnt roasted flavors come out as it warms .... taste is of fresh roasted malts, coffee, dark chocolate, caramel malts and a rich burnt roasted flavor as well  .... mouthfeel is thin and a little oily .... dry thin and roasted finish .... lovely stuff abv hidden very well
UPDATED: JAN 29, 2014 A great coffee aroma and flavor. The oatmeal addition works wonders for the mouthfeel. This is one of my favorite beers out there.

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle, thanks to clownoisseur. Pours dark black with an oily, tan head. The aroma is dominated by green pepper/coffee. The flavor is where this beer shines, cocoa, coffee, roasted malts, caramely. The flavor is fantastic, sweetened creamy coffee.

Pours a black brown color with almost no head. Aroma has a very strong black coffee nose with a more modest roasted malt note late in the nose. Nose is pretty one dimensional. Flavor starts off with a very smooth black coffee note and quickly transitions to a slightly sweet, roasted/black malt flavor. The roasted and toasted notes of the malt come through over the strong black coffee notes. The oatmeal can be felt and adds a much needed body boost. Tastes and feels like a coffee with cream in mixed in. Body is perfect and the low carbonation keeps it feeling silky smooth. Overall a damn good beer. The coffee is balanced well with the sweetness and the mouthfeel really makes this beer spectacular. One of the better coffee brews out there, in my opinion.
Coffee is not my favourite flavour In the world but this is quite nice. Coffee. On tap at republic mpls.
Pours black with tan head. great fresh coffee aromas and flavors.. Smooth and strong. Excellent.

Bottle in Fort Collins, thanks to adnielsen for sharing. Pours a deep brown color with white head. Roasty, coffee, green pepper aromas. Roasty, coffee, pepper flavors. Kind of weird that Im getting peppers in the flavors, but not bad.

Bottle @ home with jcnielsen. Rotbox offering. Pours a deep brown / black appearance with a brown head. Green coffee bean, dark chocolate, roasty aroma. Fairly smooth flavor albeit a bit thin. The coffee has faded but there is still a nice chocolate, marshmallow flavor. Probably a bit past its prime.

Pours brown to black with a thicker tan head that settles to a thick ring and film and leaves some impressive clingy lace. Nose involves plenty of roast coffee, oatmeal cookies, dark bitter chocolate, suggestions of smoke and wood, nuts, and a touch of dark pit fruit. A fair sweetness, quite bitter. Lighter-medium body, slick and oily yet a bit chalky, with a drying bitter coffee finish. I appreciate that its on the dry side. Good stuff.

Bottle:
pours black....with a creamy, dark tan head.
Dark chocolate and coffee aroma......intense.....
Creamy, bitter chocolate and sweet, roast coffee flavor.....oatmeal...
A slight ash bitter....
A truly great, great beer.

12o bottle shared. Pours not quite opaque brown. Off white head. Aroma of roasted malts and lots of fresh coffee. Very pleasant on the nose. The flavor matches the aroma with lots of roasted malts and fresh coffee and you get some of the oats on the back end. Very well made for a porter.

Pours black and pretty opaque. Small beige head recedes quickly. Slight lacing and little retention.

Nice roasted coffee aroma backed by chocolate and cocoa. Not terribly complex, but solid.

Similar flavor. Tug of war between the coffee and cocoa mostly with chocolate in the background. Coffee element seems stronger while its cold and as it approaches room temperature cocoa and chocolate come more to the forefront. Whichever flavors are more prevalant, a nice roasty bitterness pervades.

Medium bodied. Decent carbonation.

Not the most complex beer Ive ever had, but still a very tasty one and well made. Good yin and yang between the roastiness and maltiness.

Bottle. Pour is deep black with a finger-wide tan head. Aroma is instantly of coffee with background notes of toasted grain and bready malts. Flavor is subtly sweet at first and transitions into a bitter coffee finish. Nice body, a little over-carbonated.

Bottle. Deep, dark and devastating. Nice nose with malted biscuit, cocoa and molasses. Coats the tongue well, small off white head and left light lacing as I conquered it. Very lovely palate with a hint of boozey afterglow.
A sweet coffee flavor with sweet sugar. Caramel and a few hops. Dark roasted color with light head.

Bottle from Neal - thanks!  Black pour with a rocky tan head.  Aroma is heavy with coffee followed by roast, chocolate (bitter and sweet), and vanilla.  Taste is chocolate, coffee, roasty oatmel, and some darker malt notes with slight bitterness.  Smooth, almost silky mouthfeel.  Very well done roasty coffee beer.

Blackish brown with small wispy light brown head, lasting. Aroma has lots of roasted malt, coffee, sweet. Flavor matches. Medium body, roasty coffee finish. Clean, slick and creamy with great balance. Very nice palate with smooth finish.

Strong aroma of coffee, yet light and refreshing.  
Very smooth and delicious taste.  Coffee, malt, a little toffee.

Bottle to snifter. I generally dont read reviews before raring a beer, but I looked these over tonight to decide whether or to have this or a Peruvian Morning. I was pleased by the ratings and description of bold coffee flavors so here goes. Pour here is dark cola color - nearly black - with a one finger light brown head that reduces to a bumpy film after a couple of minutes. Pretty well laced in the short run.  Rich aroma of coffee and cacao beans.  Taste is very coffee forward with a touch of cola and burnt wood and hop bitterness. Flavors are blended exceptionally well the beer has good balance. Silky mouthfeel from the oats. Creamy coffee finish. Very well done.

Bottle thanks to a trade! Pours black with a brown head that dissipates quickly to the edges. Aroma has a nice combination of coffee and bitter chocolate with a light roast underlying. Flavor is nice as well with a good balance of chocolate and coffee that are supported by dark grains and roasted malts.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2015 From BandC. Slick mouth feel from the oats, roasted barley and coffee flavors. Rich flavors but thin feel not in a bad way but a traditional porter as a thirst quencher way. Serving: Bottle

Pours an opaque, very dark brown with a taupe head. The head attenuates quickly with very little sudsy residue on the glass. Not much beyond coffee on the nose. Some oats. But, of course, who can fault them for that, given the name of the beer. Nice smooth, slick, and wet mouthfeel. Theres quite a bit going on with the flavors. A lot more than the nose would lead one to expect. Coffee up front, but the flavor begins to become much milder as it advances. It finishes with a little dark ripe fruit and some salty watermelon. Incredibly interesting. Usually, a coffee stout finishes with coffee flavor and coffee acidity. Impressively engineered, but not my favorite.

Ar: Dark coffee, bakers chocolate, some mild berry fruitiness.
Ap: Brown, hazy - small tan head with poor retention, leaves a bit of nebulous film.
T: Chocolate and medium-roast coffee, moderately sweet - some tropical fruitiness and berries - low bitterness - finish is smooth coffee and caramel.
P: Medium body, very silky - carbonation is medium - finish is medium-dry.
O: Nicely balanced, fully-flavored porter - great coffee and chocolate flavors - also, the palate is great (velvety smooth) - great beer.
Delish!  Smooth, like the perfect couple of coffee cooled down.  But poured into a fine beer.  And served with love.

12 oz. bottle pours an opaque dark brown, almost black color with small tan head and a bit of lacing.  Aroma is full of coffee and tobacco with noticeable roasted grains, condensed milk, and a bit of dark chocolate.  Taste is slightly bitter (like coffee).  Mouthfeel is very creamy, without very much carbonation.  Body is medium to full.  If I drank beer for breakfast, this would be one of my top picks. A well-crafted strong porter which reminds me of a good oatmeal stout.
A nice surprise. Strong coffee flavor, velvety and rich. Delicious every sip.

12 oz. bottle courtesy of Queenholly. Thank you a lot for this one! Black color with fast dissipating tan head. Nose is a pleasant mix of fresh coffee beans and chocolate malt. The oatmeal gives a nice full body and complements the flavors really well. The flavor is chocolate up front with an Iced coffee with cream following. Also getting vanilla with hints of caramel. The finish is dry and roasty with a lingering coffee aftertaste. A nice creamy, silky texture. Really close to Founders Breakfast stout or any high end coffee based stout or porter. Top tier without question. If you enjoy coffee brews find a few fresh bottles! Excellent.

bottle to glass shared with friends thanks to madbeerbaron thank you 
poured a jet black no real head i smelled coffee but didnt taste any it had some really good maltyness to it but thats about it overall it was a good try
Bottle thanks to Kyle. Pours black with tan head. Nose and taste of roast coffee, vanilla beans, roasted chocolate malts and flaked oats. Smooth. Medium body.

Bottle - thanks Kyle! Pours opaque deeeep brown with a medium creamy brown head that slowly dissipates with great lacing. Aroma is coffee and cigarettes, ash, dark roasted malts. Flavor is the same, ashtray in a glass, but in a good way. Lightly sweet, some coffee bitterness and a bit of ashy astringence in the far finish. Full bodied, creamy mouthfeel - the influence of the oats is apparent immediately. Reminds me of Founders Breakfast stout. Pretty tasty stuff.

Aroma is dominated by freshly roasted coffee with a touch of roasted malt. As the beer warms the chocolate becomes more noticeable but it is a bit one dimensional towards the coffee. 
Pours a dark brown, but not black with light brown highlights on the edges. Light mocha colored head of moderate thickness that recedes steadily to the edges but lingers. Medium lacing with medium low legs. 
Flavor starts with some nice roast and chocolate with a solid coffee character. Mid palate the coffee hits strong but it fades towards the end and blends with a bitter chocolate note in the finish. The bitterness is moderate and the finish has a nice dark chocolate character. 
Mouthfeel is medium full bodied and creamy smooth with medium low carbonation. Low astringency with low alcohol warmth. This is a very smooth, easy drinking coffee porter. 
Overall this beer is very enjoyable. It has a really nice coffee flavor, though a bit strong in the aroma. The oatmeal really helps the creaminess of the mouthfeel. 


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle at home. Pour is pitch black with a small tan head and great lacing. Big over-roasted coffee, light green peppers, vanilla, wood, roast, bready rye, vanilla, and chilies in the aroma. Taste is huge roast, big chilies, dark chocolate, espresso, sweet vanilla, and oak with a big bitter finish. Slick mouthfeel with medium carbonation. Pretty tasty porter with a great base, but needs a little tweaking; the coffee is way too bitter and gives off heavy, spicy green pepper notes.

Refrigerated 12 oz. brown bottle poured into a snifter.  Pours black with big brown and small light beige head. Little lacing, medium/thin body, low carbonation, and strong coffee aroma.  Taste is coffee.

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle. Pours a darker brown it with a thin tan head of foam. Aroma is big cofree with some vanilla beans and malty notes. Taste is coffee and vanilla. Coffee doesnt devastate like some other coffee beers, but its definitely there. Roasty in the finish.

Draft at Jerrys. Black with good, frothy, tan head / Rich, toasty nose of tobacco, oatmeal, roast grain, and coffee / Medium to full body, a hint watery, creamy and chewy, lightly sweet with some astringency, excellent balance and bitter finish / Flavors of dark roast coffee, caramel, grass, oatmeal, condensed milk, and tobacco / A solid, well balanced porter.

Bottle from 4 pack. Pours a nearly jet black with tannish head that settled and dissipates. Aroma is coffee and a burnt roast malt. Taste is interesting mix of coffee, chocolate, toffee and slight oatmeal notes. A nice balance between the bitterness of coffee beans and the sweetness of roast malt chocolate. A very good porter.

Pours an inky black with a medium, creamy brown head. Aroma is rish chocolate and coffee. Flavor os toasty malt, milk chocolate, bitter coffee, caramel, and nuts. Full, creamy body with soft carbonation and alcohol masked almost entirely. Very nice brew.

Poured into a glass tulip.

Aroma: A strong coffee scent, with slight roasty chocolate notes. 

Appearance: Poured very hard for about 2 fingers of tan head, which disappears quickly. Opaque black in color.

Taste: A strong roasty coffee flavor, with that pleasant bitter coffee after-taste on the back of your tongue. 

Palate: Dense and creamy.

This tastes similar to Founders Breakfast Stout, but I prefer the Founders. This is still, a delicious brew.

Bottle from trade with Crajun.  Pours near pitch black in color with small brown head that fades quickly.  Nice aroma of fresh light roasted coffee, vanilla ice cream, sweet caramel, and very light chocolate.  Taste is a nice blend of the aromas.  A bit more roasty than I expected from the aroma and theres a touch of smoke.  Very nice vanilla cream taste to go with the fresh coffee.  Finish is smooth with a light bitterness.  Body is fairly thick and a tad chewy.  Really nice imperial porter.  Thanks Kevin!
Pours black, lack of carb, dissipates to slight rimming head.  Coffee nose with a pretty subtle sweetness.  Sweet start, caramel, and coffee flavor, mild astringency.  A  bit thin, but pretty solid.
Black pour no head.  Coffee, burnt malt, some sweetness.  Like founders breakfast, less sweetness, a touch more coffee.  Drinks bigger than 7.5%.  Suprised by this one.  Very good effort.

Bottle from trade with crajun. Black pour with a fairly subtle aroma of roasted malt and coffee. Flavor is balanced, consisting of roasted malt and coffee. Carbonation is soft. Not as big a flavor as I was expecting but nice, and easy to drink.

Founders Breakfast Stout, you have met your match. Poured into 12 oz snifter. Pours dark brown/black with laced tan head if poured slowly.Nose is full of coffee and roasted malt. Well balanced, think, oily palate. Tastes of Coffee, toffee, and again the malt. Honestly, there isnt much more you could want from a porter/stout. Well done!

Bottle from Sonoma.  Coffee, coffee, coffee.  Heavy coffee nose and initial taste...not sure what differentiates stouts from porters in this case, but...

Smooth with minimum bitterness...medium to full body / mouthfeel....not terribly profound a good sipper...tasty

12oz bottle, purchased at Sonoma Cellars Delavan.  Pours a dark dark brown color with a tan head.  Aroma is coffee, more coffee, roast malt, a little burnt. medium on the palate with average carbonation. Flavor is bitter, coffee, some bittersweet chocolate, burnt toast, maybe a little nutty. Good, but one dimensional.

On tap at Brixies. Served in a snifter.

A: Pours a jet black with a thick tan head forming on the pour. The head has nice retention and leaves nice splotchy lace behind.

S: Coffee grounds up front with a little bitter roast. Some milk chocolate as well. Toasted cereal grains in the periphery.

T: The taste is pretty similar to the nose. Pure coffee beans, lingering chocolate and some toasted grains. A little roasted malts with a slight astringency to it.

M: Pretty thin with a medium coffee presence on the finish. Medium carbonation.

O: A little to thin for me overall. It detracted from the drinkability somewhat. Nice flavors overall though.

Serving type: on-tap

Bottle. Pour is black with a tan head, good retention/some lace. Aroma is coffee, chocolate, roast, vanilla, cream. Taste is coffee, vanilla ice cream, chocolate, roast. Palate is soft, creamy, light bitter finish. Really outstanding take on a coffee porter/stout.

12 ounce bottle. Pours a totally black color with a medium thick brown head. An odd nose, its coffee, but I get green pepper. Excellent flavor: roast, massive roasted coffee and milky sweet coffee, lingering chocolate and coffee. A full creamy palate. Damn good.

Pour out of 12 oz bottle, so glad to finally be able to try this.  Thick oily black pour with nice 3 finger caramel colored head, aroma brought huge notes of roasted coffee bean, espresso, slightly green coffee, dark bakers chocolate, roasted malt, even a slight campfire note, slight metallic note as well.  Taste is a mix of thick green coffee, nice oats, chocolate, roasted malts, slight smoke, nice caramel, toffee, even a hint of vanilla, finishing roasted, more coffee with a slight bitter and roasted quality.  Nice and thick, but not oily on the palate.  Nicely done.
Bottle @ home...It pours pitch black with a small tan head.....The aroma coffee, roasted malt and chocolate.....The flavor is strong coffee beans, chocolate and vanilla notes.......very nice.....

12oz bottle from Binnys Niles. Pours near black with small tan head. Aromas of roast malts, loads of coffee, vanilla, and some chocolate. Flavors of coffee with roasted malts, chocolate, and vanilla sweetness. Finishes with nice amount of sweetness to balance out coffee, Body is pretty full for a coffee beer. Real nice coffee beer and I am glad they decided to brew this one again.

From 2009 bottle, courtesy of dpjuart. Dusty and lightly stale brewed coffee, with licorice, caramel, paper, and very mild smoke. A wee bit of soy. Sweet, mild alcohol. Dark black-brown clear with thin tan head. Medium-heavy body with medium-light carbonation. Starts medium sweet with caramel, licorice, coffee, and mild smoke. Really nice and aged fairly well. Finish is smooth with brown sugar and coffee. Smooth after with light vanilla and oak.
Slick mouthfeel, better than some of their other porters. Flavor is coffee all the way, slight tea. If you like coffee get some.

12 oz bottle. It pours dark brown with a tan head. The aroma has potent spent coffee grounds with some dark chocolate and hints of caramel sweetness. Mostly coffee in the nose. The flavor is the same. HUGE coffee presence with a silky smooth body (thank you oatmeal) with good, dirty cigar-like roastiness. Another one of those "if you like coffee, youll love this" kind of beers. Mild hints of caramel in the mid palate. Excellent coffee beer.
Bottle. Earthy roasty coffee and chocolate aroma. Thick black with a small brown head. Espresso, light chocolate, ashy / earthy flavor. Full body, moderate carbonation.  Really great coffee flavor.
Crazy coffee taste and aroma.  Straight up coffee beans. Live it.  Thick oily pour from tap at fork.  Delicious
12 ounce thanks to Bacterial. Nice dark pour with creamy head. Chocolate and coffee throughout.  Light body. Definite oatmeal stout flavor - slight milk as well in its creamy texture.
Dark, rich palate of HDD and SSDs. I dont want anyone to pass out, but they do. What say you!

Bottle. Deep brown/black body with a fizzy beige head. Big aroma of rich black coffee, chocolate, vanilla and light roast. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes lightly to moderately sweet and lightly to moderately bitter with the bitterness lingering well into the finish. Medium body, watery texture and lively carbonation. Taste of coffee with light cream and a splash of chocolate. Slight acidic tartness enhances the flavors. Too bad the watery texture doesnt match the rich aroma.

Enjoyed on tap at the Map Room in Chicago, IL while celebrating a friends birthday.  I remember this being exceptional.  Served in a Chimay chalice, appearance is a murky dark caramel brown with a thin off white head.  Aroma of pure dark coffee, bitter, with notes of chocolate.  Taste is fantastic, huge coffee notes with roasted malt, chocolate, cocoa, vanilla, just a lot going on with this one.  Very much enjoyable.

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2013 Pours a jet black color with a finger length head that dissipates very quickly and leaves a thin ring of lacing around the edges. Smells of nice dark, bold, roasted coffee. Almost an earthy quality to it, but basically like smelling fresh coffee beans. As it warms, get more vanilla qualities. Taste starts very much like it smells: a bold coffee bean flavor, along with tons of roasted qualities and a hefty amount of bitterness as well. Then in the middle, the oatmeal silkiness shows through and smooths it out, along with some sweet vanilla qualities. Then the finish is a nice medley of the bold, roasted coffee bean flavors and the sweet, creamy vanilla notes. Has a pretty full body with a creamy, sticky mouthfeel. Definitely has some porter qualities to it, but is on the verge of a stout. This is right up there with their dirty old man, which is my favorite porter. Not as complex as the breakfast stout by Founders, but is still up there with it in my opinion. Tyranena knows how to do their porters.

Pours standard black-brown with light brown head that sort of lingers throughout. You can smell the coffee and it comes out on the palette, but the coffee mellows out with the malts of this porter which makes for an amazing aperitif. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours black with a good khaki head.  From the aroma, Im getting lots of coffee.  It literally smells like a cup of coffee with just a touch of chocolate thrown in.  With the taste, it is more of the same, but even more potent.  The only difference is that more of the chocolate comes out.  Of course, the aftertaste is coffee and chocolate with some bitterness at the end.  Medium bodied with a creamy texture.  There is a bit of carbonation in here as well.  Overall, this one is straight forward with what it is trying to do and what it offers.  And this is accomplished very well.  Try this one for sure.

Bottle to snifter (thanks jmikolich). Looks good; black with beige lacing. Smells solid; dark-roasted coffee and malt. Tastes like it smells with a smoothness from the oatmeal thats nice on the palate. Nice.

Draft. Pours nearly black with a small creamy tan head. Aroma is coffee, roast, chocolate a touch of an earthy hoppiness. Flavor is sweet and roasty, again plenty of coffee and chocolate, dark chocolate with some bitterness in the finish. Medium to full creamy body and a soft carbonation. Very tasty.

Poured from a 12 oz. bottle into a short-stemmed tulip glass.

Pours a deep, dark mocha brown with a velvety two finger light beige head. Excellent retention and abundant lacing. Holy coffee on the nose! The combination of deep aromatic espresso and roasted malt is very inviting, indeed. Opens with roasted malt notes that slowly take hold, joined with rich espresso. Finishes with a pleasant level of bitterness undoubtedly a combination of the contributions of the hops and coffee. Velvetly, silky and creamy medium body that is exceptionally pleasing on the palate. Perfectly carbonated. This beer is nothing short of impressive. The use of coffee is masterful. The coffee perfectly complements the base beer, elevates it, and the result is an incredibly well-balanced beer. One of the best American Porters, frankly one of the best beers overall, that make use of coffee that Ive enjoyed.

Near black with a thick medium brown head. Earthy hops, muddy, bitter coffee, and lactose-like sugar. Has the bitterness of dark roasted coffee, but the sweetness from the oats comes through. Heavier, syrupy body.

Bottle from Brook-Falls Discount. Pours a very, very dark brown with a tannish head. Some spotty lacing. Aroma has rich luxurious coffee with a lot of chocolate and caramel, and a nutty presence. Wow! Taste is of roasted malts, strong bitter coffee, some sweet choco-caramel and bitter nuts. Strong, powerful and rich. Finishes roasted bitter with sweetness in the end. Overwhelming smell. A bit of smoothness (more oatmeal??) would make this world class.

Thick black with very light head which was brown sugar in color.  Aroma was sweet chocolate and coffee.  The roastedness was hidden well with a ton of coffee coming forward.  Taste was so smooth with pure coffee, chocolate and just a hint of vanilla.  Mouthfeel is incredible on this one with the perfect amount of carbonation (very little).  Top notch for a coffee porter!!

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2013 12oz bottle to glass; one of 8 recd from friends driving down from WI - will add to ratings after a couple more - great aroma; roasted everything!  5 for palate - exxxremely smoooooth.  I didnt get a ton of flavor or any complexity in taste - slightly more as it warmed??  will drink next one closer to room temp and add more thoughts..

Intense dark coffee roast aromas and some chocolate. Taste is a nice creamy chocolate with a big bold coffee flavor, outstanding beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours dark black with very little head. Strong aroma of coffee and the taste follows that line as well.   Pretty good. Great try if craving coffee.

12oz bottle from blue max liquors in Burnsville, really solid and rich coffee porter, with a tinge of hops shining through in the finish.. its like a breakfast stout flavor that keeps me wanting more.

12oz to snifter.  Aroma is 100% coffee, like you just opened a fresh bag of beans.  Dark as night.  Thin head.  Flavor follows the aroma.  Palate is oatmeal smooth with the sweetness that sticks to your gums.  In your face coffee beer.  Very nice.

12 oz. bottle. Pours dark brown almost black with a tight tan foamy head that fades to a wispy film. Aroma has strong coffee notes some nuts and roasted malt. Taste is bitter coffee oatmeal and roasted malt some bakers chocolate with a faint dark fruit in the finish. Palate is full and slick with a nice fizzy drying finish. Solid!

12 oz bottle poured into a snifter glass. Pours black with a small chocolate colored head that fades quick but leaves lots of lacing. Aroma of fresh coffee beans, vanilla and chocolate. Huge fresh roast coffee taste up front, with the vanilla beans and dark chocolate coming in strong afterwards. I cant accurately describe just how huge this taste is! Full body, very rich, thick and creamy with an active carbonation and long finish of chocolate. Making this as a porter instead of a stout was a great idea, as this flavor balances out perfectly! Simply top notch!

On tap at Old Fashioned, also bought a 4 pack the same day.  Pours  black with a tan head, the aroma is straight roasted coffee with a ton of chocolate, very nice, the flavor has a nice front end of coffee with a sweet finish of the chocolate, mouthfeel is very creamy and nice, wow, delicious.
Dark beer smells strongly of coffee and chocolate. Taste is thick, roasted coffee with malty sweetness. This is a big, bad, robust beer.

On tap at the source.  Deep brown-black pour with minimal head.  Amazing nose of deep, deep freshly roasted coffee.  Period.  Unbelievably fresh.  Flavor is more of the deep, freshly roasted coffee and roasted malt.  Faintest of cocoa and brown sugar.  Coffee is dominant, however, out to the finish.  Medium palate makes this way too drinkable.  No coffee acidity.  I dont drink coffee, but seriously...Coffee lovers rejoice!

4th October 2010Opaque black brown beer, no real head. Light semi soft and semi dry palate. Mild coffee, some lactose sweetness. Some well integrated and subtle chocolate and a nice undertone of cherry fruit. Finishes semi dry and with the chocolate coming to the front. Well joined up and tasty.
tap at 800 Degrees a few months ago - Pours black with a rich, roasty, coffee aroma.  The flavor is dark roast coffee malt with a little chocolate.  Its big and bold with a full body.  Very tasty!

RBSG 2010 another bottle by my favourite enabler. Brownish red brew with a small tan head that didnt stick around. Aromas that seem thick - large coffee, bourbon, wonderful dark chocolate and some alcohol, touch of molasses - not all that complex but damn good. This tastes awesome - probably the best beer Ive had today. Just the right amount of soft bakers chocolate, ample tasty bourbon, very dark roast, faint fruit - maybe a cherry flavour, coffee - all around amazing, drool inducing flavours and aromas. Smooth and oily goodness, long roasty chocolate finishes.

Reviewed from notes.

Pours a near black color with a thin mocha head. The nose brings quite a bit of coffee as well as roasted malt. Some hints of chocolate. The taste is about the same, with the addition of a nice creamy mouthfeel. Good roasted coffee notes and some pretty deep malt. Mild amounts of chocolate in the background. Quite smooth and easy drinking. A good winter brew.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-24-2010

12 oz. bottle shared by STLWill- thanks again, Will! I guess this is the non-barrel version of Devil Over A Barrel, which we opened first. Pours a dark brown color, basically opaque, with a small tan head. Looks just like the other Devil. The aroma has the same peppery character without any of the nice barrel notes to complement it; also notes of coffee, dry roasted malts, dark chocolate, toast, and nuts. Flavor of roasted malts, dark chocolate, peppers, oats, toast, and earth. Medium-bodied, with low carbonation and a dry, gritty mouthfeel. I liked this one, but not quite as much as the Devil Over A Barrel. Surprised at the amount of peppery flavor in both.

Pours a solid black with a thin tan head that dissipates immediately. Smells of coffee. In fact thats all I can smell. Tastes of roasted malts, little bit of chocolate, and oh yeah some coffee. Thick creamy body, smooth silky mouthfeel, moderate carbonation, oh yeah and some coffee. Great coffee, er uh I mean beer. I actually enjoyed this brew, but I think I let it sit in the cellar to long, Id have loved to try this fresher.

Enormous thanks to flandersned for this long sought imperial porter. 2007 vintage. and wow was it worth the wait. aside from all the details, this beer is really a barrel aged porter; so many of them i have are really closer to a stout. this one has a nice light quality present, super well balanced and tasty, slight rye-like notes everywhere, wow. pours a dark brown black with ruby edges and a small brown head that fades fasts and leaves lots of spotting in my glass. the aroma is light, spirited, roasty, delightful. the taste follows, huge flavors and whatnot, but not really all that heavy. the body is excellent, thick full, creamy, oily, bright, all at the same time. this one is a gem, probably my favorite out of their imperial porters. lots of coffee plofile throughout. just an epic beer. really.
smells nice and fresh.  dark chocolate, brown sugar, smoke, tastes thick and pretty delicious.

A: snifter. Pours an abyss-like pitch black with a tan head that drops rather quickly. Nice ring lacing around the glass.

S: strong rich, sweet roasted malt aroma with a big coffee nose. Some oatmeal characteristics make the nose very pleasant. A lot of chocolate and toffee as well.

T: chocolate and coffee of the bat. The oatmeal really smoothes this brew out very well. Big toffee flavors are the primary ones in this brew. Some hints of vanillas as well, along with some serious caramel.

M: not as thick as I anticipated. Mild carbonation level. Very intense palate.

D: A very tasty and drinkable porter. It kind of reminds me of Gonzo, but not nearly as hoppy. A solid brew in my opinion, especially with the additional ingredients. Definitely worth of a try.

Bottle shared at a recent BA/RB tasting...  Poured near black with a tan head.  Oats and sweetness mixed with bourbon, which was a great complex mixture here.  Coffee notes were mild.  Also sweet with vanilla and oak.

(12oz bottle with my likeness on it, Tyranena has not responded to my inquiries unfortunately, thanks to bu11zeye for this one though) clear ruby/espresso, no bubbles. Nose of coffee, sweet fudge, graham cracker and marshmallow. Taste of cola root, dry cocoa, fudge, with a smooth and flavorful finish.
bottle, thanks to thirdeye11, pour s dark brown with no head, aroma of roast coffee, smoke and caramels, flavor is vanilla, chocolate and coffee,

12 oz. bottle courtesy of a trade with fata2683.  Pours very dark brown, just about black with a thin tan head that fades to a ring after the first couple of sips and leaves a thin layer of foam with each sip.  The aroma is wonderful and is filled with coffee and chocolate with notes of licorice.  The flavor is roasted malt and coffee with chocolate and a bit of tobacco.  Mild roasty bitterness at the finish with some light alcohol warmth.  A tad light in body.  Overall, an enjoyable beer.
Bottle. Pours a black color with a small off-white head. Has a roasted malty coffee aroma. Sweetish malty coffee flavor with some hints of chocolate. Has a sweetish roasted malty coffee finish.

Shared by GuyinChicago on the RBSG bus! Pours a deep reddish brown with an espresso swirl head. The aroma has lots of coffee and deep cocoa notes along with some olive, cherry and ash in there as well.  The flavor had deep coffee tones with some chocolate. The beer is dry, roasty, and bitter with some mild fruitiness.

Bottle, thanks to GuyinChicago for the share. Pours cola brown, medium off-white head, poor lacing. Nose is oats, woodsmoke, roast, chocolate milk. Flavours of smoke, pumpernickel bread, pumpkin seeds. Very solid.

12oz bottle pours a slightly viscous, opaque black with basically zero head.  Aroma is coffee with cream, brown sugar, molasses, well toasted whole grain bread, nutty.  Flavor is sweet, coffee, cola, pumpernickel, whole grain toast, oats, a little lacto sugar.  Finish is really silky in the mouth, medium bodied with a lasting sweetness.

Bottle from ughsmash. Dark brown, minimal tan head. Aroma and flavor straight up coffee grinds. As it warms some chocolate comes through, other than that, not much going on. Oily/slick palate/mouthfeel.

Poured from bottle into tulip glass. 
Bottled on 11/06/08. Pours a very deep brown but not quite black color. Tan head that quickly dissiapates and leaves a light tan collar around the glass. Small bubbles. Coffee and Dark Chocolate aroma. Smooth coffee flavor giving way to bitter chocolate aftertaste. Slight pick up of the bourbon flavor left from the barrels. Heavy mouthfeel
Very tasty, but be warned that if you dont like coffee or bourbon, this is not the beer for you.

bottle pours pitch black with a medium dark tan head.  Aroma is rich bakers chocolate and coffee aroma with some roasted malt.  Flavor is rich burnt sugar and black patent with lots of silkiness and a strong coffee finish.  Another home run of the BGW series.

Bottle. Pour was jet black with a nice dark tan head. Aroma was of strong chocolate, roasted malt, and a nicely balanced, yet strong coffee flavor. Body was real full with more coffee and chocolate balancing nicely with the malt and moderate alcohol flavors. Very nice brew. Complex, yet well balanced.

Bottle.  Pours a pretty dark, almost black, but still like a deep burnt smokey quartz/charred petrified amber-like color.  The head above isnt there anymore, really...cept a few bubbles clinging to the side of the glass.  The nose reminded my of chocolate rumballs, with an evident layer of coffee, and even some oatmeal cookie.  Flavors combine all that in the nose atop a somewhat silky and oily body..the coffee is the strongest characteristic and seems to linger the longest, the oatmeal is still evident, its not all that sweet though...almost even a bit dry, though there is a chocolatly touch to the coffee entrails.  Carbonation is semi-low, bitterness more a side-effect of the coffee and roasty malts than from the hopping.  Alcohol nicely hidden.  I like this better than the rye porter rye-barreled beer I had yesterday from these guys.

Bottle from a trade with MIBRomeo. Pours dark brown/black color with brown head. Huge coffee aroma with some chocolate. Flavors of coffee, sweet milk chocolate and roasted malts. Medium to full body with soft carbonation and a creamy mouthfeel. Thanks Chuck.

The beer poured black with a one finger head, the aroma was sweet with coffee notes.  The flavor was rich, roasty with coffee notes.  The palate was light fizz with a rich mouthfeel.  Overall a s good beer with coffee present as advertised.

A: The pour is dark, dark brown (almost black) with a bit of tan head.

S: The nose is full of coffee with a bit of oatmeal. I dont normally enjoy coffee, but for some reason, in beers like this, it is absolutely amazing.

T: The flavor follows the nose. Strong coffee flavors with a nice roasted malt component and quite a bit of oatmeal flavor to smooth things out.

M: The body is medium to full with moderate carbonation.

D: I am not too much of a fan of coffee on its own, but its absolutely amazing in this beer. I wish I had a few bottles of this to drink. A great beer.

12 oz bottle received in a trade with a ratebeerian. Pours a nice black with a creamy tan head. It looks really good. The smell is very heavy on the coffee. The taste was overwhelming with coffee and not in a good way. this was so bad I had to pour out three quarters of the beer. 
Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-05-2007 19:52:35

Bottle from a trade a while back, cant remember from whom.  Pours a clear dark brown heading toward black, with a thin dense dark tan head that falls rapidly.  Spicy jalapeno, coffee grounds, touch of sweetness.  Medium bodied, coffee, roast, again a bit of jalapeno.  Finishes up with a touch of sweetness, almost some cream, and coffee roast.  The pepper doesnt exactly detract, though does seem a touch out of place.

Bottle courtesy of decoman from TBS....thanks!  Pours a dark brown/black with minimal head.  Smell is definitely coffee....smells like a mocha.  The coffee is more subdued in the taste though - the oatmeal definitely comes through.  The sweetness of the chocolate is present, but not overdone.  Good beer.

Thick Black pour, thin brown head that fades to a ring.  Aroma is rich luscious coffee grounds with some sweet chocolate. hints of vanilla and some robust oatmeal.  Flavor is intense coffee bean, angel fingers soaked in coffee liquor.  Bitter chocolate, some light roast, with a silky delicious mouthfeel that is a result of the oatmeal Im sure.  Simply delicious.  Thanks to Googzoid10

12 oz. bottle - thanks to daknole for recently hooking me up with one of my top wants; dark brown pours with trace tan head forming along the edges; bourbon mixed with coffee are the primary aromas with some chocolate, oats and oak mixed in; texture is thin and flavor profile very reminiscent of Devil Over A Barrel, which is or isnt the same base beer??  anyway, this one is a warm and fuzzy going down with lots of coffee and malty sweetness; more sticky than dry in the finish; not quite as good as DOAB, but pretty damn good; yea, I wish I lived down the street from these imperial porter-making fools; sigh

B ig coffee and chocolate nose and thin brown head that dissipates quickly. First flavors are sweet chocolate with coffee on its heels. Mouth feel is smooth and creamy,  syrupy  with a slight light bite of alcohol and bitterness.The finish is one of sweetness and chocolate bitterness with some cherry notes. The bitterness of the chocolate is just enough to offset the sweetness. Very nicely balanced. I do like this one and will keep coming back.

On tap at Stub and Herbs.  Pours a black body with a thick brown head.  Aroma is coffee, chocolate and caramel malts.  Flavor is bitter and the palate wonderfully thick, creamy and smooth.  Not terribly complex but a easy, tasty drinker.

Bottle via trade.  Pours jet black with a one-finger tan head that leaves thick lacing on the glass.  Aroma is freshly brewed coffee, roast, and oatmeal.  Flavor is fresh coffee, oatmeal, heavy roast, and a hint of dark chocolate.  Palate is smooth despite the coffee bitterness, and a little grainy, which I like in a coffee beer.  Overall a nice breakfast porter, up there with Founders Breakfast Stout and Mikkeller Beer Geek Breakfast as far as beers I want to drink in the morning go.  Oh, who am I kidding, Im an alcoholic.  Ill drink any beer any time of day.  The -bal aged version of this beer is just a little better.

Bottle pours black with thin tan head that dissipates quickly.  Aroma is coffee roast, dark caramel, and vanilla .  Opulent mouthfeel.  Flavor is dark coffee roast, subtle sweetness, and finishes with a cocoa chocolate shot of espresso silkiness that is warming as you drink it.  Very nice brew.

Pours jet black. Huge, thick, surging, moussy tan head that falls quickly away to nothing.  A beer cant look any better than this.  The aroma is dominated by sweet raw coffee along with hints of vanilla,caramel and a touch of smoke. The taste brought on another dimension that seems a bit more complex than the aroma would have you believe. Tastes of expresso, molasses and a hint of chocolate malt. Creamy and very, very smooth. Great drinkability.

12 oz bottle.  Pours thick and pitch black with tan head.  Aroma is deep roast coffee, chocolate and malt.  This one has a jalepeno pepper character that I have not had with past bottles.  It is fairly odd an detracts from the great beer that it is.  Flavors are very similar with the jalepeno flavor persisting.  It has a great body and mouthfeel.  This is the first of several bottles Ive had that have had this peppery flavor.  It has been sitting in my basement for some time, so that is the probably cause.  Hopefully they will make this one again.  I will score it based on my previous experiences though.

12 oz. bottle from Rileys Wines of the World in Madison, WI.  Very dark, nearly black, pour with a very thin beige head.  Big roasted coffee aroma with dark chocolate and oatmeal (wow, bet you didnt see that coming).  Certainly a beer for coffee beer lovers as this one offers plenty of that in the flavor.  Some bitter chocolate on the finish.  This is a very good beer.
Pours black with almost no head.  Aromas bitter dark chocolate and oats.  Flavor is totally coffee with a little chocolate covered oats.  Creamy palate coating.  Excellent beer.

Pours a dark pitch black color with a thick foamy beige head. Good retention and nice lacing. Dark roasted coffee aroma with hints of chocolate maltiness, oatmeal and toffee. Roasted oatmeal chocolate maltiness with a nice roasted coffee flavor. Hints of toffee, nut and very subtle hops with a dry finish. Very smooth because the roasted coffee flavor is not overwhelming. Extremely quaffable and delicious.

Bottle thanks to iowaherkeye. Pours with a very deep brown, near black body with a smallish brown head on top of it. Aroma is rich and earthy with chocolate and nice roast. Some dark fruits and vanilla. Taste is rich with vanilla, deep roast and velvety coffee. Very nice, drinkable and exploding with flavors that are hard to believe for a malty 7.5% beer. Thickish viscosity. Medium carbonation.

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2010 Picked up at steves in madison and certainetly worth the trip poured black and thick with minimal tan head  looks like a stout and also taste better than some I have had,this truely is a kick ass brew aromas of roasted malts.vanilla,coffee and chocolate taste is of all with a sweet smooth finish and no coffee bitterness

12oz shorty bottle.  Gift from CaptainCougar, thanks man!  Opened with a minimal hiss.  Opaque black color, minimal quick fading head.  Roast chocolate malt and coffee aroma.  Smooth on the palate, with some smoky chocolate coffee flavors on top of a smooth Oatmeal infused body.  Pretty right on for the style.  Some interesting dry cocoa coffee bitterness as well, which really balances it all out.  A very nice beer, which remains pretty drinkable.

Thanks to ucusty. Bottle. Aroma of coffee, milk chocolate, musty/earthy tones. Flavor has more of these odd musty notes for me, subduing the coffee, with some sweet/roasted malt. Semi-creamy palate, but the mustiness is there too. Surprisingly didnt really work for me.
12oz bottle into a pint glass.  Aroma is all coffee. Flavor is a tad sweet with big coffee. Mouthfeel is super thick & creamy.  I was hoping for more out of this.

Bottle from Cellars Wines and Spirits on 06/27/2009. Clear dark brown body with ruby highlights and a medium creamy light brown head. Big coffee aroma, with some peppery notes and a bit of roast and caramel. Big coffee flavor, some peppery notes, a bit of caramel and chocolate with a roast background. Medium body with moderately low carbonation.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours dark brown/black in color with a small tan head.  The aroma is fine coffee, dark chocolate, roasted, with a touch of sweetness.  The flavor is more strong coffee, dark chocolate, oatmeal sweetness, roasted, with a dry finish.  Medium bodied at best; actually it could stand a bit more thickness.  This is still a very solid imperial porter.

Bottle.  Pours black with hardly any head.  Aroma of coffee of course and some sweet malt and molasses.  Flavor is quite loaded with coffee with some sweet oatmel.  Palate is a little thin, I think a coffee imperial porter needs to be a bit more robust.  I preferred Devil over a barrel over this original version.  It was certainly good, but not as great as I had expected.
8/4/7/4/14 (3.7/5)

Lovely coffé smelling thing, mild hops in the nose, mostly just good coffé really with subtile chocolate aromas. Mouthfeel is extremely slick but a bit too thin, flavour is a bit too thin aswell but pretty tasty with smooth coffé and chocolate. Light chocolatey aftertaste.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours black with little fizz and just a ring of dense fine head. Aroma of coffee and lactose/slightly sour milk and some subtle fruity and bourbony notes.  Sweetened coffee flavor with plenty a dry, roasty finish. Silky smooth with a low but tight and prickly carbonation. Really nice beer overall - in the top tier of overtly coffee oriented styles.

(Sample Date: 6/27/2009   Source:Other)   Coffee imperial oatmeal porter. Hmmmthat sounds like a Stout! Lots of fresh coffee and roast in the aroma. Black with a small dark tan head. Big fresh coffee flavor with roast and some chocolate behind. Full creamy mouthfeel. Finish is dry and moderately bitter with coffee and roast lingering. Excellent!

(Trade from Pantatrap) At first poured no head into glass, but it did finally raise about 3/4 cm. Lots of bubbles coat the side of the glass. Dark black/brown body with no light penetration. Very robust aroma of chocolate and black malts. Coffee clearly comes out in the flavor. Thick body. Definately falls closer to the porter end of the spectrum than stout. Would be on my list of beers I go back to if it were available in the SF Bay Area.

(Bottle courtesy of Headbanger) - Color is a solid black with a tight tan head.  Aroma is deep with a dry roasted coffee scent.  Taste is smooth, rich and roasted.  Starting with a bold medium body it goes down with a creamy feel.  Finish is a big bold roasted coffee flavor with a faintly sweet chocolate taste to it.  After taste is dry with the coffee lingering on.  This is a kick ass Porter with big coffee flavors.

Bottle courtesy Dan the San Diego man. Reddish black pour with a thin tan head. Aroma is dry bitter coffee. Smooth silky oatmeal body with lots of chocolate, coffee, espresso in the taste. Dry bitter coffee finish. Good stuff.
Coffee explodes out of the aroma.  Cold coffee flavor.  Actually get a little oatmeal flavor on the finish too.  Nice.

pours deep brown, thin mocha head with some nice golden lacing on the glass.
Aroma is just a superb coffee bomb with tons of roast goodness and malts.
Taste, superbly coffee, grainy with oat for a nice thick palate. Lots of coffee and roasted malts with a faint bitter coffee finish and some chocolate.
I could drink this all day, this is wonderful.

Rating #666.  12oz bottle shared by ogglethorp.  Darkest brown pour with a thin tan head.  Malty aroma with lots of coffee and cream.  Coffee flavor up front followed by cream and chocolate with a bitter coffee finish.  Amazing brew.

Bottle, courtesy Gillard. Brownish black and red pour, some bubbly lacing, slight head. Big coffee nose, chocolate and roast. Chocolate flavors, oats and coffee, pretty bitter, but balanced and drinkable.

bottle poured a dark chestnut brown bordering on black with a frothy dark tan head with some brisk pouring. aroma has dark roasted coffee, rich malt, bourbon, and dark chocolate. quite rich. mouth feel coats well without becoming too thick and heavy. dark roasted coffee pops first, dark coco powder, heavy malt body, oatmeal flavors and texture, leading to some bitterness at the end. amazing how this is so rich and hefty but it remains drinkable and enjoyable.

12 oz bottle courtesy of Three Cellars (Franklin, WI). Pours a thick black pour, notes of brown, largely opaque, with small brown head that dissipates a bit and laces pretty well. Aromas are a nice dry malt, a touch of smoke, with bourbon and barrel and coffee coming through. Not as heavy on the barrel as anticipated, pushing a bit of smoke and roast more over. Initial is coffee, smokey or ashy, some dryness mixing with roasted malt, keeping this brew away from any sort of sweetness rule majority. Oatmeal and chocolate come in a little further into the body, with a touch of oak and vanilla. This beer is a little underbarreled for me, personally, and pushes coffee, dryness, and a bit of smoke (Likely the coffee chosen) as its dominant factors. Good, different. Cheers!

bottle via trade with FlandersNed (thanks, steve!) pours a silky, very dark brown, almost black, with a thin, dark tan head and solid lacing. aroma is great with strong, bitter coffee and chocolate dominating with notes of roasted malt and bourbon. flavor is delicious as well with big roast coffee, smoke, and dark chocolate over notes of brown sugar, oatmeal, and roasted nutty malt with a long, bittersweet coffee finish. mouthfeel is smooth, medium bodied, with light carbonation. overall, a great coffee forward imperial porter.

Bouteille de 12 oz, rapportée par Dany du Wisconsin. Arômes très intenses de grains de café torréfiés et de chocolat. Robe noire et opaque, peu de mousse et faible effervescence. Très onctueuse et veloutée en bouche, les grains de café fraîchement torréfiés sont très présents et accompagnés dune touche de chocolat. Finale douce et légèrement sucrée. Très bon.

Im really starting to worry. Theres half-eaten cupcakes everywhere, were all out of paper clips, and the curtains smell like doob.. http://www.wtso.net/movie/64-The .... .if you stuck your head into a bag of fresh columbian/jamaican coffee beans, you might get a hint of what this beer smells like ... Oh my God! This dude does the best Flanders! .. . cold dark coffee and the darkest frozen dark chocolate flavours.. . Homer: Eh? Same old garbage!

Bart: Ahahahaha, this guys always on!

Bottle, thanks sersdf.  Dark pour with a thin oily head.  Heavy coffee and chocolate nose.  Tannic roastiness, alcohol, vanilla.  Bourbon and caramel.  Full round flavor with a bitter coffee and chocolate finish.  Slightly earthy.

Bottle, thanks to WeeHeavySD for sharing! Pours a deep dark brown with an off-white ring. Intense coffee aroma, with malt, chocolate, brown sugar, and oatmeal. Taste is smooth, with a  lot of coffee, oatmeal, malt, wood, and some chocolate. Lingering coffee flavors. Really great.

Bottle, pours an almost opaque, black body with red hues and a thin, light brown head.  Aroma is mainly espresso/coffee with hints of roasted malts and cocoa.  Flavor is more of the same with some chocolate and licorice flavors and a hint of oatmeal.  Smooth mouthfeel; light carbonation.  Medium bodied and a little watery near the finish.  The coffee flavor is nice, but tends to dominate a little more than I would like.

12oz bottle. Pours viscous looking black with very little, light brown head, good lace. Smells of a hint of sweet roasty malt and tons of coffee grounds. Tastes the same, lots of coffee grounds, slight lingering sweetness. Smooth, full body, ok carbonation.

12 ounce bottle courtesy of cdumler. Thanks! Pours a very dark reddish tinted brown color with a thin head. Aroma of strong bitter chocolate with sweet chocolate and milky notes. Taste is bitter coffee, chocolate and oatmeal. Full bodied.

Thanks Gillard for the share.  Pours dark cola brown with an off-white head.  Nose is lots of coffee, vanilla, lactose, and spices.  Flavor is lots of coffee with oatmeal to mellow it out.  Chicory, spice, oats, and vanilla round out this enjoyable beauty.

Black in colour with a thin but lingering beige head, light lacing.  The aroma is just incredible, intense coffee roast, espresso, good sweetness, very malty in general.  The flavour seems to thin out a bit, high sweetness, some coffee roast, ashy and smoky.  Sweet mouthfeel, medium body, medium carbonation.  Finishes with huge coffee roast, sweet and lingering.
This has crazy amounts of coffee but doesnt have the body to back it up.  Not overly balanced but fun to drink.
355ml bottle obtained in a trade with TheCheeseMan, thanks Dan.
Opened on July 30, 2008.
Bottled on February 2, 2007.

Bottle via trade with biniek13. Pours a cola brown with a nice medium light brown head.  Nose is full of fresh brewed french pressed coffee and fresh ground coffee. Yum! Taste is pure coffee goodness. Hints of oatmeal but it is covered with coffee. 
Mouth is pretty heavily carbonated, full mouth, becomes a little syrupy at the end. If you love coffee this is a great one!

Bottle.  Ze pour was the darkest of brown with a late-forming tan head.  Aroma of chocolate, coffee and the promise of hope for the future.  Flavor is super malty, a bit of earthy hops, and lots of fudgy love.  Smooth as satin from the oatmeal and incredibly rich.  An amazing porter, for reals.

2008 Bottle - Thanks buckybeer! - Pours a dk dk brown with a lasting tan creme head...aroma is chocolatey, mocha malt, toasted grain...flavour is similar huge chocolate, coffee...like jamoca almond fudge from 31 flavours...nice bitterness, a bit of vanilla...coffee is present but not overwhelming...sweet and malty with a roasty wheaty kick...another winning wild brew from T...

Bottle - This stuff is liquid sexy. Pours oil black with a big bubbly tan head. The aroma is big coffee, chocolate, and caramel. Big sweet, roasty malts hit the nose too. Taste like coffee grounds, dark chocolate and big roasty malts. Theres a little bitterness at the end that seemed a little off. But thats my only complaint. The mouthfeel is the real star--it felt like I was drinking a milkshake, in a good way. Im glad Ive got three more of these to drink.

12oz from a little while ago via trade.  How I missed this I have no idea, but hell yeah glad to try it now.  Pours black with a light brown head.  Nose is rich with tons of coffee and a kick of oatmeal  Taste is sweet rich and robust with a nice layer of oatmeal and a kicking layer of coffee.  Yummers.

Poured into a chalice at room temperature this beer left a very small head.  It smells of strong coffee and oatmeal. There is still lacing after the first few sips.  It tastes first of strong coffee followed by roasted malts and oatmeal.  This is a great beer but I wish it was a little thicker in body.  It has a clean medium carbonation and makes for a wonderful session beer.  Highly recommended.

Bonus bottle from mgumby10.  Thank you!  Pours black with an amber tint and a faint brown head of foam.  Brimming with the aroma of jalapenos and dark cocoa.  Smells like pepper jack cheese.  The spice gets mellowed by the cocoa flavor in the taste to create a really harmonious balance.  This is a real treat.

Bottle graciously shared by nbutler11.  A beautifully full dark chocolate and coffee aroma.  Both smell and flavor are delicately but noticeably spiced with a dark pepper of some kind that balances the sweetness perfectly.  Very sound.  Almost unfair that its a regular porter.

12 oz. bottle - Poured black with small tan head.
Aroma - coffee grounds and oatmeal.
Flavor - I tried the Devil Over the Barrel before this one and prefer the one aged in bourbon barrels. This beer has good coffee flavor with nice roasted taste.
Palate - medium mouthfeel with average carbonation. Finish is mildly bitter and short.
Overall - Great coffee porter but I much prefer the Devil Over The Barrel!!!

Pours a silky deep black and has the most perfect head Ive ever seen. Aroma is like a cup of quality bold coffee. Flavor is damn fine as well. Taste of coffee is pretty heavy, but its somehow balanced perfectly. Very smooth but medium thin mouthfeel. A nice twist on a porter and definitely worth a try.

So after about 15 minutes of confusion, Im ready to rate this.  The top label says "The Devil Made Me Do It" with the little man on top saying "cool beans."  Except, the bottle label is identical to the "Devil over a barrel" bottles I have... soo either a labeling error... or they just use the to top labels to discern the different beers?  After a few sips, this is definitely not the barrel-aged version which Ive had before, but equally as delicious.  Smells like a black cup of morning coffee with a touch of oatmeal and cream.  Fantastic coffee stout "porter" whatever, doesnt taste like expensive coffee, just vividly translated fresh coffee, one cream and light sugar.  This beer is really up there with Kentucky Breakfast, Peche Mortel, and Beer Geek.  The after-taste is so authentic dinner the morning after going out.  Fantastic body, full mouthful but very drinkable, ever so lightly sticky, super soft larger carbonation.  [after reviewing xnoxhatexs notes... I do taste some of the caramel and of course the chocolate]
Bottle poured black with tan head. Aroma is roasted malt, coffee. Taste is chocolate, roasted malt, slight bitterness, and coffee. Finished smooth and a very enjoyable porter.
Good coffee flavor-very potent. Some crystal coming through. Very smooth palate, but slightly thin when matching against flavor strength. Good chocolate mixed in with the roast.

Bottle. Pours a deep black color with very minimal head. Flavor is....delicious. Roasted malts, mild black coffee, oatmeal, sugar, cinnamon, the list goes on. Body is full with an oatmeal smoothness. Finish is lingering, slightly sweet and coffee bitter. This stuff goes down REALLY smoothly. Havent met a Brewers Gone Wild! that I havent liked yet.

2007 12oz bottle acquired in trade. Consumed January 2009, at least 2 years old. Pour is decidedly black with an aroma of very roasty coffee and burnt malt.  The flavor is chocolate up front with the coffee bitterness rounding it out.  Actually a very nice mix.  Holding up very well after so long.

Pours a oily dark brown/black color with  a small tan head. Nose of black malt, coffee, roasted malt, sweet caramel, cream. Initial taste is semi-sweet chocolate, creamy, oatmeal, coffee. Body is slight watery drowning out the flavor, flavor is to me is mild. Palate duration is average. Decent head retention with spot lacing. Overall a good porter and very drinkable.
UPDATED: JAN 1, 2010 TAP: Happy Gnome (St. Paul, MN) on 1.17.09. Black pour, small head. Huge coffee/chocolate smell and flavor, thick mouthfeel. A little bitter late. Terrific beer.

Pours a dark brown/black with a thin tan head. strong espresso roast and chocolate aromas.
Flavour carries dark roast coffee and chocolate maltiness, a creamy body with a light charred bitterness in the finish.

Bottle.  Pours very dark with a small tan head.  Nose of coffee, with some sweet malt notes mixed in.  Taste is very roasty, again lots of coffee, some chocolate.  Oatmeal isnt really present in the taste, but helps to beef up the body and reduce the bitterness.  Very nice full body, smooth finish.  Overall, an excellent beer.

Bottle.  Black pour with a very small tan head that mainly sticks around at the edges.  Armoa is full blast coffee.  Some notes of chocolate and molasses are there, but the coffee leads by far.  Flavor has some great coffee notes, but not in an overbearing fashion at all.  Flavor introduces more chocolate than the nose and the oatmeal gives it a silky smoothness that all porters wish they had!  Really a high quality beer.  I would like more of this!!
Poured pitch black with as tan head. Roast coffee aroma. Fairly sweet with notes of roast malt, coffee and cocoa. Decent effort.
12oz bottle. Solid dark black color with a light tan head. Strong coffe aroma. Roasty malt and coffee flavor as well. Pretty good.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text:
Bottle poured into a snifter produced a couple of fingers worth of tan head on t pitch black body

Aroma of Coffee filled my nose, Yup that about it.

The flavor of coffee is very dominant in this one. The oatmeal helps tame the bitterness and ads some sweetness to it. The mouthfeel is topnotch, nice and thick what I expect in a Porter.

A great drinking porter, I enjoyed it a lot. I would gladly drink it again If I could get it

Very dark pour with a tan head. Aroma of straight coffee with a hint of chocolate. Smells like breakfast. The flavor is similarly breakfasty - tons of great coffee, some rich oatmeal notes and some milk chocolate. Mouthfeel is incredibly creamy. This is a truly awesome brew, very impressed.

An almost black pour. Roasted malt with light coffee and chocolate on the nose. Good coffee with chocolate undertones. Decent bitter finish. Thick rich and creamy palate. Very solid with a just right warmth. The way a porter should be for me.

This poured black in color with a moderate head of very fine light beige bubbles.  The nose immediately screams of rich coffee followed by oatmeal, roasted malt and milk chocolate.  In the mouth this was medium-bodied, concentrated and rich.  The palate adds some creamy vanilla flavor to go along wtih the coffee and chocolate from the nose.  The carbonation is fine but keeps this fresh and felling light.

Black pour with tan head. Aroma is all coffee and a bit of sweetness. Flavor is roasted malts and coffee. Mouthfeel is a bit thin, though. Kind of like Founders Breakfast stout, but thinner. For a coffee beer, this is pretty good though.

Bottle from KingpinIPA. Pours near black with a tan head. Huge aroma of roasted coffee beans and espresso. Mouthfeel is full and creamy. The flavor again has loads of coffee, burnt wood, roast, and toasted oats. This is definitely a breakfast beer.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2009 Pours darkest brown with a thin, quickly vanishing tan head.  Aroma is all coffee, very bright and aromatic.  Flavor is similar, the bright espresso coffee elements blend very well with the bittersweet roasted barley porter element.  A little bit citric, turning earthy, more like coffee grounds, on the finish.  Medium body and carbonation, tingling mouthfeel.

Bottle shared by wolf.... Aroma was coffee beans before they were ground up. Almost espresso like. Great aroma. Taste was pretty much the same. Taste just like coffee beans before they were ground up and a light touch of oatmeal. The texture was light, but not weak...Easy to drink solid beer that  I enjoyed. Thanks wolf for sharing your good beers.

Like coffee beers?  Then get this.  Tranena has done it right with The Devil Made Me Do It.  Sold in a 4 pack for $8.99 and worth every penny.  Black and oily, heavy coffee smell and smokey roast.  Medium carbonation and long-lingering coffee aftertaste.  There are few things better in the beverage world that beats this beer.  Barley Island’s Black Magic Java Stout comes close, but this is top-notch and a must-buy.

Poured dark black into a frosted pint glass, very little head.  As a coffee lover, the aroma was amazing (very strong dark coffee aroma).  First sip reminded me of the strong cup of black coffee I had this morning, delicious and relaxing.  Was surprised to see this has a 7.5 ABV, will have to make sure I finish this slowly!
